content.text: A Disclaimer

I am a marketing man. Nothing more. But also. We live in a time when anyone can know anything. Information is one click away. And I like connecting dots. And a lot of people are saying things that irritate me. So here we are. Now I have a reply ready.
When a man tries to sell me a car straight from the garage at 1600 Pennsylvania Avenue. I look under the hood. I check the odometer. I see what leaks.
Not claiming to be Woodward or Hersh. Just a guy connecting what's visible. The world leaves tracks in the dust. I follow them on weekends.
Take this how you will.
Now to the matter at hand...
Intro
Villain Or Hero?
Donald Trump is back. Once again. No one agrees on what exactly we're watching.

To some he's a familiar character. A vindictive narcissist with no attention span. With a talent for setting fire to institutions simply because they exist. Erratic. impulsive. obsessed with dominance. A man lashing out at enemies real or imagined. Governing not through strategy but by instinct. Grievance. Spectacle. Some describe Trump as a malignant narcissist. A man characterised by vindictiveness. Impulsive.

To others he's a bold visionary. A disruptive force executing a daring economic doctrine. Someone willing to do what polite leaders won't. Able to tear up broken systems. Challenge sacred cows. Wage total war on China. On bureaucracy. On globalist orthodoxy. A man who sees the world as a deal to be made. The ‘MAGA’ agenda has been described as a paradigm shift. Economic protectionism.

With the unveiling of massive tariffs and threats to global alliances, the second narrative has grown louder. Trump recently declared a national emergency under the International Emergency Economic Powers Act (IEEPA). Imposing sweeping tariffs of 10% on all imports. Higher rates for countries with significant trade deficits. China is hit. The European Union is hit. The penguins are hit. These measures are seen as calculated geopolitical moves by some. The blueprint for new global trade dynamics.
And. Some push the hero story even further.
Some argue Trump is playing a calculated geopolitical hand. That we're watching a master tactician leveraging economic pressure. Diplomatic risk. Chaos.
To some this is not destruction. It’s control.
Analysts have noted that Trump's policies reshape international relations. Repatriate supply chains. Disruptive. Yes. But in favour of U.S. interests.
But let's step back for a second.
I’m confused. Is this The Art of the Deal?
Or is this The Art of the Conceal?
What’s behind the headlines? Behind the gestures? Behind the noise?
It seems to me that something bigger and deeper is unfolding. A pattern that connects finance to foreign influence. I see media strategy and a game of destabilisation that spans over decades.
Ah. It also all seems perfectly suited for this presidency.
Lets take a look.
Part One
The Wall of Maturities
I want to understand what's really happening. I’ll forget the slogans for a minute. I’ll follow the money.
The United States faces a financial bottleneck of historic proportions.
There are $7.6 trillion in Treasury debt maturing by the end of 2025. Approximately 21% of the $36.56 trillion total federal debt as of March 2025. Source
Gross federal debt is projected to reach 124% of GDP by the end of 2025. Driven by persistent deficits exceeding 6% of GDP and quarterly refinancing needs of approximately $1 trillion. source
Economists call this a 'wall of maturities'. And it's not a metaphor. It's a concrete liquidity cliff.
I’d call this a nightmare.
Why does it matter?
Because debt, like power, is all about timing.

If you borrow smart. At low interest rates, across long maturities. You buy flexibility. If you borrow for brief periods, you're locking yourself into a cycle of constant refinancing. And if rates rise? You're trapped. Paying more just to stay afloat.
Now here's the twist. That wall wasn't built by Joe Biden. It was constructed, brick by brick, during Trump's first term. Build the wall, baby!

Rather than spreading out maturities, Trump's Treasury increased reliance on short and medium term debt, especially from 2017 to 2020, capitalising on historically low interest rates and eager bond markets. source
It looked clever. Back then. For a minute. Like not wearing a mask in public.

Faster liquidity. Lower yields (more savings). More room for spending and tax cuts without rocking the markets. But it came at a cost. A fiscal time bomb timed to explode for whoever came after Trump’s planned second consecutive term.
But, wait. Consecutive?

The timing here is telling. Had Trump secured a second consecutive term, he would have surfed the wave of his own borrowing while leaving the inevitable crash to whoever followed him in 2025. Presumably a democrat. Ah, what an ego trip that would have been.
A classic case of privatising gains and socialising losses. Politics as usual.
But fate has a wicked sense of humour. Trump missed the second half of his game. The one he was counting on.
But he had to come back. He had to for several reasons.

Of course Trump wants to make America Great Again, of course. Of course he wants the best for everyone. But maybe. Maybe there is someone else counting on Trump being the POTUS. Someone who’s watching from the side window. But we’ll get to that.
So yes. Trump came back to the White House just in time to pick up the check of the dinner he ate with his friends. The bill collector now stands at his own door.
Markets are watching. Interest rates are volatile. Refinancing costs are climbing. And the U.S. is looking more like a systemic risk than a safe haven.
It's not a great place to be negotiating from. Unless, of course, you were never planning to negotiate at all.
Part Two
How to Spin a Wreck Into a War Cry
So what do you do if you're staring down a financial cliff that you helped build?
If you're Trump, the answer isn't to climb down carefully. It's to blame the terrain. Declare war on gravity. Start yelling about who else might fall off if they don't start agreeing with you.
Because that's the thing. Trump doesn't see crises the way others do. To him, a crisis is just another opportunity to frame a story. To cast a villain. To be Trump.
So the narrative kicks in. On steroids.

It's China's fault. It's the Federal Reserve's fault. It's NATO leeching off American strength. It's the globalists. The allies. The bureaucrats. Denmark. The traitors. The enemies of MAGA. It’s everyone except the man holding the detonator.
And it works.
When the conversation shifts from how did we get here? to who do we punish for this? Trump wins the frame.
This isn't governance. It's theatre.
It's not a strategy built on solutions. It’s a strategy built on controlling the emotional energy of the moment.
Rage. Loyalty. Fear. Distraction becomes the deliverable.

And if the real economy starts to hurt. If refinancing costs spiral. If markets wobble. If interest payments start eating the federal budget. That's not a failure to Trump. That's fuel. Fuel. More fuel. And fuel, in a world that looks like Mad Max, saves you.
Fuel burns and the flame is more proof that the system is rigged. That the institutions are corrupt. That only Trump can fix it.
This is not a bug.
The script.
And it's one he's run before. He’s done it in business. He’s done it in politics. He’s now doing it on the global stage.
Really? Let’s see.
Part Three
Chaos Is Not the Anomaly. It's the Shady Business Model
Markets rattling. Allies alienated. Debt deadlines looming. A tariff war against the entire planet. This might look like chaos.
But if I zoom out. It's not chaos. It's consistency.
This is exactly how Trump has always operated.
It's how he built his name. His buildings. His mythology. Not on steady growth or clean books. On debt. Spectacle. Opaque dealings with shady partners.
Want to understand Trump's presidency? Start with his real estate.

Let’s take a look at Trump-branded properties. These sold over one-third of units to anonymous shell companies before 2016. Including buyers tied to Russian oligarchs and criminal networks. These opaque transactions exemplified real estate laundering practices. source source source source source
Some even suggest this partnership has been going for decades. source
His business partner in multiple ventures? Meet Felix Sater.

Felix has an impressive criminal record. Documented ties to both Russian and Georgian mafia. Someone with a good role in the proposed Trump Tower Moscow deal during the 2016 campaign. source source source source
The Trump Tower Moscow deal?
Yeah. Sater offered to secure Kremlin support for the project by gifting Putin a $50 million penthouse. source source source
Everyone’s a friend.
This wasn't business as usual. It was business as camouflage. The goal was never just to make deals. It was to build the illusion of power while someone else carried the risk.
Debt wasn't a tool. It was the product. Opacity wasn't a flaw. It was the design.
And now that same structure. Borrowed power. Blurred responsibility. Explosive exposure. This is what Trump has slammed onto the global economy.
Except this time the asset on the line is not a tower.
It's the United States. And us. The rest of the world.
Part Four
Flood the Zone, Control the Frame
Trump is the brand. Steve Bannon is the manual.

While Trump bulldozed his way through politics with instinct and ego, Bannon quietly built the operating system. Not a platform of policy. A system of information warfare tested through Cambridge Analytica. Fine tuned to manipulate democracies in the digital age. source source source source source source
At its core, the strategy is brutally simple.
The opposition party is the media… All we have to do is flood the zone. Every day we hit them with three things… They'll bite on one, and we get all our stuff done. Bang, bang, bang.
- Steve Bannon -
That's not metaphor. That's instruction. Bannon didn't just invent slogans. He engineered confusion as cover. source

While the media scrambles to chase headlines. Tariffs, indictments, NATO threats, 'liberation day'. The real machinery keeps moving underneath. Policies get signed. Alliances are broken. Debt deadlines are reshuffled.
Democracy is distracted. Forgets to blink.
This isn't reactive. It's doctrinal.
Cambridge Analytica didn't win on persuasion. It won on precision disorientation using stolen data to target voters not with facts. But with feelings. Rage. Identity. Tribal loyalty.
The Oval Office is captured by anything that bypasses logic and turns political conversation into a hormonal warzone.
And now, that same technique is being scaled up. Not just to win elections. To control perception in the face of national and international collapse.
If the economy cracks? It's because of the Fed. Or China. Or the deep state. Or immigrants. Or Germany. Or BlackRock. Or journalists. Or anyone else convenient enough to absorb the blast.
The goal isn't to fix the system.
The goal is to overwhelm the system and own the story that follows.
This is not improvisation. This is a method. A campaign. A programme.
And it's working.
Part Five
The Kremlin Knew This Play Before Trump Did
Trump is the brand. Steve Bannon wrote the manual. Putin wrote the doctrine.
Not on social media. In the KGB.

Putin's career didn't begin in politics. It began in the shadow world of Soviet intelligence. For 16 years, he worked as a foreign intelligence officer in the KGB, specialising in tactics the Soviets called 'active measures.' source source source source
What are active measures?
Disinformation
Infiltration
Propaganda
Destabilisation of political institutions
Cultivation of useful idiots abroad
It wasn't just about spying.
It was about shaping public perception in other countries. Eroding trust, magnifying division, creating just enough chaos that a society could no longer distinguish signal from noise.
Sound familiar?

Putin took power. He modernised the doctrine. Out went the mimeographed pamphlets and secret meetings. In came state supported media, cyber armies, bot farms, memes, proxy conflicts, and targeted psychological warfare. Not against armies, but against electorates.
Trump, whether knowingly or not, stepped right into that system. And suddenly, the tactics aligned.
Flood the media with noise? That's classic active measures.
Attack institutions with fake scandals? Active measures.
Use polarising cultural issues to divide a population? Active measures.
Create loyalty not through policy, but identity and paranoia? Active measures.
Putin didn't invent Trump. But it would sure make sense to presume that he created the conditions that made Trump powerful. And his chaos contagious.
And whether Trump believes it or not. Whether we believe it or not. His leadership style mimics the architecture of Russian strategic subversion.
Break trust. Exploit anger. Undermine alliances. Reposition the autocrat as the only stable point in the storm.
Active. Measures.
Putin thought he needed spies to work for him.
Let me rephrase that. We thought Putin thought he needed spies to work for him.
Trump and Bannon delivered. Press conferences, trade wars, tweets. Everyone delivered.
Meanwhile the West got trapped. Divided. Distracted. Debt ridden. Further from unity. Further from coherence. Further from the very foundations that kept it strong for 70 years.
Active. Fucking. Measures.
This isn't theory. It's a pattern. And it's playing out in real time.
Part Six
The Art of Collapse
OK. So this Isn't the Art of the Deal. It's not even the Art of The Conceal.
Trump built a wall. But it wasn't on the border. It was on the books.

A wall of maturities. A fiscal time bomb he wired during his first presidency. Short term debt stacked high for short term gain. Now that the bill has come due. Trump returned not with a plan. With a megaphone.

He blames. He spins. He declares enemies. Not because it solves anything. Because it shifts the spotlight. And while the economy creaks under pressure, the narrative gets louder. More tariffs. More threats. More battles. More chaos.
Behind him. Steve Bannon floods the zone.
Muzzle velocity.
Truth: Devastated. Drowned out by noise.
Democracy: Distracted.
And behind that. Further back. Almost out of sight?
A man who doesn't need to rig elections because he can fracture trust. A man who doesn't need tanks because democracies tear themselves apart from the inside.
Trump isn't Putin's puppet. That would be too simple. Seriously?
Trump is Putin’s perfect vehicle.
The drive? Down a strategy built on destabilisation. Deception. Decay.
Trump brings the wreckage with a smile. He sells it as greatness.
The wall of debt. The wall of noise. The wall of delusion.
This isn't leadership. This isn't negotiation. This isn't the Art of the Deal.
A sleight of hand on a global scale.
Where instability is repackaged as strength.
Where collapse is mistaken for courage.
And if we don't call it what it is. Clearly. Publicly. Now. We may wake up to something far more severe than a deal gone bad.
Note to Self
When analysing patterns of power, follow the money first.
Then the noise.
The real story lives in what happens while everyone's looking elsewhere.

articles.title: The Forgotten Power Of Limits
articles.author: Ray Tarantino
articles.excerpt: Today Microsoft stands tall as a trillion dollar company. But it began with less memory than a modern email signature.

content.text: Today Microsoft stands tall as a trillion dollar company. But it began with less memory than a modern email signature.
Bill Gates has just shared the original Altair BASIC source code.
I saw it. It made me stop. It made me think.
Today machines generate code faster than humans can read it. Language models spit functional programs without breaking a sweat. Yet this primitive source-code-poem matters more.

I cannot code. Not well. Not in any way that works the first time. But I respect the magic of it. The way it conjures something from nothing. Like an old wizard working ancient spells. So I asked a friend who knows these things. A real code wizard. His answers left me stunned.
That code remains the coolest code I’ve ever written to this day…
- Bill Gates -
Birth of an Empire

Gates and Allen wrote this code in 1975. The Altair 8800 was the first real personal computer. Just a metal box with blinking lights until their interpreter gave it purpose. Suddenly hobbyists could write programs. Run loops. Process inputs.
The machine.

Consider the limitation. Four kilobytes total. Four fucking kilobytes. Modern programmers waste that much space declaring their dependencies. Today we build bloated applications that struggle to say hello.
True Craft
They wrote in 8080 assembly. Raw code that speaks directly to metal. No safety nets. No frameworks. No libraries. Every instruction had to count. Every byte mattered.
Efficiency was not a goal. It was a necessity.
Now? Nauseating. Startups chase billions in valuation before building anything real. Everyone certain they will be the next unicorn.
But. This code never screamed scale. It whispered elegance. It needed no keynote presentation. No seed round. No bullshit investor deck. It simply had to work.
The constraint created genius.
The First Software Battle
This code also marked the first software war.

Hobbyists shared it freely. Gates answered with his famous Open Letter to Hobbyists—you can read more about it here. He argued software held value. It deserved protection. This moment transformed computing culture. Software shifted from free hobby to serious business.
That letter planted the seeds for software licensing. For intellectual property laws. For the entire economic engine that powers technology today.
The irony doesn't escape me. The same company that once fought against free sharing now embraces open source. Evolution isn't linear. It's a twisted path of contradictions.
Monument of Small Things

We measure modern tech by its enormity. Billions of users. Millions of code lines. Data beyond measurement. But this tiny package reminds us revolutions start small. Not a cathedral but a cornerstone.
In our world of generated everything, we forget the struggle of creation. The human cost of making something from almost nothing.
This is not mere code. It is testimony. A four kilobyte miracle built by two young minds alone. Alone with their machine. Alone, before tech grew its monstrous ego.
In that cave of binary, the wizard cast his first spell.
And the world never looked back.
Today's tech heroes arrive with private equity backing and PR teams. Gates and Allen had a vision and the audacity to execute it within brutal constraints.
Which approach creates more magic?
I think we know.
Note to Self
Remember this when staring at blank pages.
Gates changed the world with fewer characters than a useless Google Review.
He did not wait for perfect conditions.
He did not need the latest tools.
He did not have endless resources.
He simply built what he could. With what he had.
Four kilobytes. No excuses. Do the work. Make it count.
And for god's sake stop explaining why you cannot begin. Can't you see how the beginning is the spell itself?
Your greatest limitations are not obstacles. They're the exact ingredients of your breakthrough.
I need to remember that.
Every. Single. Day.
The magic lives in constraint.

articles.title: The Selfie-Industrial Complex
articles.author: Ray Tarantino
articles.excerpt: Oh wow! Preservation and evolution really do happen simultaneously!

content.text: Oh wow! Preservation and evolution really do happen simultaneously!
I got schooled by the iconic Red Phone Box.

Walking back from Hyde Park yesterday, I paused at a red telephone kiosk with a sign declaring it ‘protected for future generations. I had my doubts, but reality hit me as two GenZs immediately pulled out their mobile phones to photograph this adorable communication touchpoint for their social media. The now legacy.
Phones capturing phones. The future documenting the past it was meant to inherit.
The Collapsed Timeline

The acceleration is dizzying. The gap between a technology becoming outdated and achieving nostalgia status has compressed from decades to years. What we think we are preserving for the future is being consumed.
Reinterpreted. Repurposed.
Right now.
The traditional model of heritage preservation assumes a comfortable timeline. We protect something valuable today for someone tomorrow. We have time.
Nope. We do not have time.
That timeline has collapsed.
This isn't just about phone booths. It's the fundamental pattern of how modern brands must approach their heritage. The half-life of nostalgia has shortened dramatically.
Vinyl records. From obsolete technology to hipster essential in 15 years.
Polaroid cameras. Dead tech to Instagram icon in under a decade.
Nintendo's NES. Outdated gaming system to collectible cultural artefact in 20 years.
Y2K fashion. From cringe to coveted in just 15 years.
The Nostalgia Manufacturing Machine

Brands that understand this collapsed timeline don't just preserve their heritage. They actively manufacture nostalgia as it happens. They recognise that preservation and evolution happen simultaneously, not sequentially.
I browsed my mental catalogue of brilliant marketers and realised how the smart ones leverage this phenomenon.
Nike. Continuously rereleases vintage sneakers that aren't actually that old.
Coca-Cola. Regularly resurrects classic formulations and packaging designs.
Netflix. Strategically reboots shows from the recent past. Think ‘Stranger Things’ fetishising the 80s.
Gucci. Deliberately mines its archives from just 20-30 years ago for heritage inspiration

The pattern is clear. These brands and data companies aren't waiting for time to make their products nostalgic. They're accelerating the nostalgia cycle. They’re betting that consumers will embrace retro products even as the original versions barely cool.
The Selfie-Industrial Complex

BT phone booths have transformed from communication utilities to cultural selfie backdrops in the span of a single generation. The future generations mentioned on that sign were not some distant heirs. They were the device-wielding influencers already standing there.
This creates an interesting psychological tension. Consumers simultaneously experience three distinct emotions.
The thrill of discovery. Finding something authentically from the past.
The comfort of familiarity. Recognising cultural icons they grew up with.
The social currency of sharing something both novel and recognisable.

Smart marketers don't just capitalise on this tension. They engineer it. They design products and experiences specifically to be discovered as nostalgic artefacts, even when they're still relatively new.
The Marketing Double-Helix
The DNA structure of this phenomenon reveals two intertwined strands.
Strand 1. Accelerated Obsolescence. Products become functionally outdated faster than ever before.
Strand 2. Accelerated Nostalgia. Products achieve cultural appreciation faster than ever before.

The space between these strands is what I like calling the nostalgia gap. It has shrunk from generations to mere years. The phone booth exists in both strands simultaneously. It’s utterly obsolete. It’s culturally treasured.

The most successful modern brands operate in both strands at once. Just like BT. They make products that replace previous iterations quickly while simultaneously celebrating those previous iterations as cultural touchstones.
Apple masters this double-helix approach. They render their own products obsolete annually while building museums to celebrate their classic designs from just a decade ago.
C’est génial!
Note to Self
The fun question isn't just ‘what are we preserving?’
It’s ‘how quickly can we embrace the reinterpretation that's already happening?’
Good brand work recognises that we're no longer preparing for a future that's coming someday. The future is already here. It’s catching up. It’s closing in by the day.
My marketing decisions should acknowledge that my legacy isn't something I'll leave behind.
My legacy is something being created, consumed, and reinterpreted. Right now.
The collapse of the nostalgia timeline means I should design products not just for their immediate utility but for how they'll be remembered and reinterpreted almost immediately.
Every product should carry the seeds of its own nostalgia value.
Time isn't a luxury anymore.
Time is compressed to the point where I'm simultaneously creating the present and the nostalgic past.
Preservation isn't for some abstract future. The future is already taking selfies with my present.
The phone booth reminds me.

articles.title: When Everyone Becomes A Digital Action Figure
articles.author: Ray Tarantino
articles.excerpt: I love patterns. Because I love noticing things. Like we all do.

content.text: I love patterns. Because I love noticing things. Like we all do.
It’s April 2025 and My LinkedIn feed is flooded with professionals transformed into action figures. Plastic versions of themselves. Digital doppelgängers. All courtesy of AI. Obviously.
It was fun the first time. Novel. Impressive even.
Then it became whatever.
Now it is completely unimpressive.
Crossing The Chasm Visualised
This action figure phenomenon is a perfect visual representation of what Geoffrey Moore describes in Crossing the Chasm. The adoption curve laid bare. Exposed. Undeniable.
Innovators. Early adopters. Early majority. Late majority. Laggards.
Each group separated by psychological chasms. Each representing different relationships with novelty and risk. Each pushing the trend forward while thinking they discovered something unique.
The later you jump on a trend the further right you sit on that bell curve. A mathematical certainty. Not an opinion. Pure statistical fact.

And these AI action figures show us exactly where people land. They become unintentional confessions of our position in the herd. Digital timestamps of our relationship with innovation. And what’s lovely about these tiny trends is just how they go full circle in a handful of weeks.
The woman roasting artichokes near Pisa will probably show me her AI Action Figure by mid May. By then the novelty will have fully evaporated. The circle complete.
The Bandwagon Effect

But what’s lurking just a couple of inches behind the Action Figure fun? What we are witnessing is the bandwagon effect in full force. Digitalised and made effortless. But at its core, this is an old story. The fundamental human desire to be part of something. To belong. To not miss out. To be relevant. To matter.

The arts industry thrives on this psychology. I remember my time at a major record company. Marketing meetings were somehow boxed into the utopian desire to duplicate specific successes. Find the next Craig David with his smooth R&B appeal. Discover another Muse with their stadium ready rock edge. Unearth a new Damien Rice with that coffee shop indie sensitivity. Identify the next Missy Elliott with her sonic foresight.
Legacy artists became branding benchmarks. Living templates. Developing acts had to fit into recognisable boxes. A&R became pattern matching. Marketing became imitation validation.

Later in Nashville, for a while, everyone hunted for the next Taylor Swift. The city flooded with blonde teenagers who had watched ABC's Nashville series. In just a few seasons, the legendary Bluebird Cafe transformed from a sanctuary of country lyrical genius to a strange hybrid of flyover beauty pageant and Top 40 b-sides.
Nothing changes. Ever.

And the truth remains that what you hear on the radio was born, organically, at least a couple of years earlier. So you are always late if the charts are your reference. Always behind the curve. Always catching the tail end of something that started elsewhere. In a basement, probably. In a garage. In a dirty studio apartment. Places where nobody important was watching. Places that stink.
Art Trend Waves Beyond Music

Trend waves. Art history shows us this pattern repeatedly. As soon as creativity meets profit. As soon as profit defines ego. That is just what happens. We are built like that. Programmed for it. Destined to repeat it.

Minimalism started as rejection of subjectivity and excess. A purification. A cleansing. By the late 1960s, minimalist works were the heroes of art markets. The very same markets they claimed to reject. Galleries and institutions commodified the movement, despite its initial rejection of market driven values. The irony missed by no one except those making money. By the 1970s, what began as a critical movement had fully transitioned into a great career path for artists. Rebellion became resume.

And so came the neo-expressionists. Inevitable. Predictable. Necessary. Rebelling—again—against minimalism's geometric abstraction and conceptual art's prioritisation of ideas over sensory experience. They embraced intense subjectivity that addressed themes of identity, nationalism, and existential angst. Raw. Emotional. Primal. Sexy. The movement reached commercial success in the 1980s, fuelled by aggressive gallery promotion and media hype. It created a clear contrast with its original anti establishment roots. Some critics argued that its market driven popularity ultimately diluted its authenticity. They were right. They always are.

How did the world respond to rebellious artists making so much money? With a punch like sensory wave of intellectual detachment driven by the Young British Artists. YBA. Three letters that changed everything. They shocked their way into global consciousness during the 1990s with provocative, confrontational works. Emerging from London, their DIY ethos meant self organised exhibitions, shock value, media talent. The movement literally exploded in value. And yes—we should probably mention that it was perfectly engineered by art collector extraordinaire Charles Saatchi. Coincidence that he also cofounded the largest advertising agency on the planet?
Nothing Changes Ever

This little artsy train of thought reminds me of an exhibition I saw in San Francisco years ago. The Stein Collection. Gertrude Stein was at the wheel of the Paris art scene during the early 20th century. She curated and marketed the modernists. She knew that rebellion sells. But she also knew you had to catch things in the underground to make it work. Not in Guerlain enhanced art galleries, but where it smells like shit. And so she went digging where others wouldn’t. Before others.

So here we are. Before Zuckerberg engineered virality & vanity algorithms, there was Gertrude Stein. The original content strategist of modernism. From her Paris apartment at 27 rue de Fleurus, she manufactured cultural relevance. Her salon was a perfectly curated feed. A physical predecessor to the infinite scroll. Each Picasso and Matisse piece strategically positioned to generate maximum conversation. Maximum controversy. Maximum FOMO. Maximum ROI.

Art just like music. You will not find the new Kings Of Leon after you hear a hip song on Top 40 radio. You find them in a dirty little Williamsburg studio with dim lights, granted you actually make it there before Williamsburg becomes the new Tribeca—obviously.
But again. Nothing changes. Ever.

And so yes, I think that Damien Hirst's tiger shark in formaldehyde being auctioned for £9.6 million has something to do with Charles Saatchi being the visionary who cofounded Saatchi & Saatchi in 1970. Which became the world's largest ad agency by the 1980s.

Saatchi conquered the planet by whispering induced need while shouting shock. He convinced all of us to buy whatever he was paid to sell. He did beautifully. Taking the best from Rosser Reeves and injecting steroids into it like it was Ribot.
Saatchi crafted a deliberate juxtaposition of conservative branding with radical ideas. He mastered tension. And the legacy is insane.
Look at this article.
Am I not trying to do just that?
Aren't we all?
When Provocation Fucks Attention In Public

The pattern? In politics. In art. In culture. In advertising. In business. The currency is memorable disruption. When a child needs attention, the child becomes annoying. It is genetic. It is built inside us.

Ok. So the YBAs were not just discovered. They were marketed. Packaged. Promoted. Saatchi was their algorithm, just as Stein had been for the modernists. Both understood that avant garde was not just about art. It was about attention.
Transform provocation into prominence. Turn controversy into currency. Stein curated her home. Saatchi curated sensation. Stein wrote enigmatic prose that provoked. Saatchi pushed art that disturbed.

You know who also knew this? Madonna. Who started her 300 million albums career with a $15,000 check by a man called Seymour Stein. Yes, Seymour and Gertrude share the same surname, but it is entirely coincidental. Although I like thinking they are part of the same family. I met Mr. Stein about 20 years ago. For about seven minutes. He was wonderful.
How did he sign Madonna?

Story goes that unsigned Madonna Louise Veronica Ciccone used to hang out at Danceteria. A club in New York City where DJ Mark Kamins would push her demo Everybody. Kamins loved her charisma. He introduced her to Stein. An industry legend already.
OK, that is somewhat normal.
What I find fascinating though is a famous conversation that followed. An exchange between Stein and a colleague—now part of the Music Industry Testament—that went something like this:
Question to Stein... "Why would you sign and promote a girl who cannot sing?"
Stein’s reply... "It is not about the voice."
Legendary.
Stein, just like his namesake Gertrude and Saatchi, understood something fundamental about culture. About attention. About what actually sells.
Buzzword Bingo
Venture capital feeds the same psychology. The funding frenzy shifts from one buzzword to the next. Like clockwork. Like seasons. Like addiction.
Blockchain.

Every startup suddenly needed a distributed ledger. Companies added 'blockchain' to their name and watched their stock prices soar. Remember Long Island Iced Tea Corp becoming Long Blockchain? Their stock jumped 289% overnight. Madness. Delusion. Money.
And the metaverse?

Facebook rebranded as Meta. Microsoft acquired Activision Blizzard. Everyone scrambled to buy virtual real estate in worlds nobody visits. Digital land in Decentraland sold for $2.4 million. It was a shitty experience back then. Now those same plots sit abandoned. Empty. Worthless.
It is like visiting west Texas. Except west Texas has Marfa. With its weird Marfa Lights. The Prada store statement in the middle of the desert on the way to Van Horn. And a real indie art scene.
Ok. I have to. It is the Marfaverse.
Focus, Ray. Back to the story.

But we should remember that there is a pattern getting all sexed up every time creativity and profit start flirting with the ego. So where has the art journey taken us? Remember how it started with the minimalists who were rejecting subjectivity and excess? How it then became search for identity itself?
Do you remember NFTs?
Everyone fucking wanted one.

Digital ownership became the new gold rush. Artists sold pixelated images for millions. Those monkeys looking stoned out of their minds? Hedge fund managers felt creative and cool for a moment. But it was a balancing act between tax free opportunities, artsy hot wallets, impulses to resist, and a cocaine-like rush to persist.

Each NFuckingT promised revolution. Each absorbed vast capital. Each took opportunity away from ramen fed innovators who were trying to design the future. And each NFT created their own distinctive bandwagons. And each time, the professional class raced to signal relevance.
Pathetically.
The pattern remains. The radical becoming commercial. The commerce of creativity. The business of being remembered. Everyone felt like a hero about their digital art.
But then the floor fell out.
From Bandwagon to Surrender
Now it is AI.
The difference. We all know it. AI is here to stay.
So while AI is the current buzzword, what is the pattern?

The pattern we can trace across these trends reveals our relationship with technology. First comes the breathless hype. Then the rush to demonstrate belonging. Finally, mass adoption signals the plateau.
It is that book again. Crossing The Chasm.
It is all coming together nicely!

Where did we start? Ah yes, the AI action figures. Pretty innocuous as standalone statements. But they reveal something more troubling than simple bandwagon psychology. Previous trend waves still required human ingenuity.
Creative exploration. Commercial acumen. People leveraging tools to create value.
This AI trend represents something different. Something profound.

The deeper problem is how these AI trends show us that while AI is not here to take our jobs—not at all—because it has no will or desire. The deeper problem is that AI is here to accommodate our profound desire to not have a job at all.
And when I say a job, what I really mean is the responsibility to have creative purpose. And what i truly mean with that is agency over the future.
We are surrendering value creation. We do it as soon as are given a chance to—immediately. Willingly. Eagerly even.
We hand our professional images to algorithms. We let machines define our digital presence. We outsource our creativity to neural networks.
And we celebrate this surrender as innovation.
Why? To feel part of something? In reality we tricked ourselves. What feels like jumping onto the bandwagon is in reality exiting the hall of relevance itself.
It is a value exchange issue. Every new action figure post represents the same transaction. A person trades their unique professional identity for temporary algorithmic novelty.
Distinctiveness for sameness. Creation for consumption.
The cruel irony?
As more professionals jump on the trend the less distinctive each becomes.
Note To Self
One action figure. Interesting.
Ten thousand action figures. Noise.
It is the exact opposite of what Gertrude Stein knew. The opposite of what Charles Saatchi knew. The opposite of what Seymour Stein knew.
These curators understood what modern professionals seem to forget. Distinction requires distance. Value demands difference. Relevance requires resistance.
Where to stand?
While I am clearly a laggard if placed on the adoption bell curve discussed by Crossing The Chasm, I do my best to at least sit comfortably.
But at least I try to remember that this stuff cannot be manufactured. That value does not come from following trends. Value comes from creating them. From seeing patterns before they become obvious.
If you are lucky, from being seen just as you inadvertently triggered something truly new.
But the truth is that we cannot all pretend to be the ones engineering the next trend. It is not a numbers game. It is not even a game.
So the ultimate self defence is not learning to kick a man with a knife.
It is knowing when to resist the comfortable pull of the bandwagon.
Because that pull.
In reality.
Is the sound of value being surrendered.
Nothing more.
Nothing less.
Share Prismatica Lab

content.text: Nompact

In our pursuit of metrics, we've created what I call 'nompact' vs impact. Where nompact represents content that makes noise but leaves no meaningful trace. It's a world where profound ideas must be packaged, hash-tagged, and optimised to survive, yet paradoxically lose their actual impact in the process.
Too much focus in the wrong place. Nothing survives.
People stuck in an endless loop of relevance.
Forgetting that real influencers, real thought leaders, real impact, all came from having the focus to develop.
I see most people sidetracked by the need to persist on a planet of algorithmic quicksand.

So I took the time to imagine an alternate timeline. One where history's greatest minds exist simultaneously in our modern digital landscape. Forced to dilute their genius to chase engagement, connections, and the fleeting dopamine hit of notifications.
Here's a glimpse into that parallel universe.
Where philosophy is measured in likes.
Wisdom packaged in bullet points.
Revolutionary thinking reduced to 'content'.
Welcome to the NomPact Vortex.
The Initial Thread, When Philosophy Gets Optimised
It all had to start with this guy. Obviously.
Friedrich Nietzsche posts:
⚡ BRUTAL TRUTH: Your 'values' are holding you back! Why conventional morality kills greatness #BeyondGoodAndEvil
After examining morality's genealogy, I've uncovered why most people never achieve their potential:
1️⃣ You've inherited a slave morality that glorifies mediocrity and calls it 'goodness'
2️⃣ Your comfort with established values is exactly what prevents your evolution
3️⃣ The 'death of God' isn't a tragedy, it's your opportunity to create meaning rather than follow it
4️⃣ Your greatest challenge isn't external obstacles but overcoming your own domesticated nature
5️⃣ True leadership requires the courage to transvalue all values, not just modify existing ones
Just published my latest book exploring these concepts in depth. Link in comments. 📚
P.S. Will be livestreaming my hike tomorrow. Join to discuss the metaphorical mountain climb of personal growth. Link in bio.
#BeyondGoodAndEvil #TransvaluationOfValues #WillToPower #EternalRecurrence
Aristotle comments:

Fascinating perspective, @Friedrich Nietzsche, though I must offer a counterpoint. Excellence isn't found in rejecting all values but in finding the golden mean between extremes. Courage lies precisely between recklessness and cowardice. Perhaps there's a middle path?
Oh, by the way. My new masterclass 'Finding Your Golden Mean' launches next week. Early bird pricing ends tomorrow! Will you join me?
Aristotle then shares Nietzsche's post with caption:
Thought provoking perspective from @Friedrich though I must respectfully disagree. Balance > extremes always! #GoldenMean
Meanwhile, Simone de Beauvoir gets a message from Hannah Arendt:
Heyyy! Have you seen Nietzsche's LinkedIn post? Total mansplaining about values and morality. You should respond with your existentialist perspective! Go girl! Need more women in this thread! xx

Simone de Beauvoir reads the thread with growing irritation. Her own book 'The Ethics of Ambiguity' sold exactly 16 copies last month, despite her deep insights on freedom and responsibility. Perhaps engaging with this trending philosophical thread could boost her visibility?
She comments on Nietzsche's post:

@Friedrich Nietszche, while your critique of moral systems is thought-provoking, it misses a crucial point: our fundamental freedom to create ourselves. We aren't defined by values (whether slave or master morality) but by our choices.

Authenticity emerges through choosing ourselves rather than accepting assigned meanings. Freedom requires recognising how we're shaped by situation while refusing to be defined by it. The greatest challenge isn't overcoming values but embracing the responsibility of freedom.
Views: 21. Down 64% from last week. Algorithm hell.
Lao Tzu can't pretend this isn't an opportunity for engagement. He gets in on the momentum. He posts on his profile:
🌊 COUNTERINTUITIVE SUCCESS: While @Friedrich Nietzsche, @Aristotle, and others debate striving, I've discovered the paradoxical power of non-action #WuWei
After years studying the Tao while working in high-stress environments, I've discovered why effortlessness outperforms striving:
1️⃣ The wise leader achieves more by doing less (wei wu wei - action through non-action)
2️⃣ Like water, true power comes from flowing to the lowest place, not forcing upward
3️⃣ The more you pursue success, the more it eludes you; success arrives when you align with natural flow
My new WuWei Meditation App guides you toward effortless achievement through daily practice.
When was the last time you achieved breakthrough results by letting go rather than pushing harder?
#WuWei #TaoistWisdom #EffortlessSuccess #ThoughtLeadership
Immediately sends screenshot of post to 5 different group chats with ‘Engagement boost pls? xx’
The algorithm hungers.
Content begets content.
One thread becomes a web and the digital spiders begin to feast.
The Algorithm Spreads Ideas As Currency
Lao Tzu messages Confucius:

Hey hey hey! Did you see Nietzsche's post and all the responses? Everyone trying so hard, striving for engagement, pushing their workshops... perfect opportunity to showcase wu wei. I just posted about effortless achievement. Maybe share and tag me so it gets more visibility? Thx man! My meditation app has only 47 downloads 😩

Marcus Aurelius sees Lao Tzu's post while checking LinkedIn during his lunch break at the dog-walking business he manages. Another rejection email from the Stoic Leadership Conference sits in his inbox. They've gone with 'someone with a stronger social media presence.'
His morning routine video series flopped last week despite following trending audio.
Marcus Aurelius posts:
⚔️ CEO CONFESSIONS: Just saw @Laozi's post on non-action and wanted to share my framework for leading through crisis #StoicLeadership
While Laozi offers valuable insights on effortlessness, as someone leading through pandemic, supply chain disruption, and market volatility, I've found stoic principles provide stability:
1️⃣ Focus exclusively on what you can control (your judgments and actions)
2️⃣ Remember your mortality daily to maintain proper perspective
3️⃣ View difficult people as training partners strengthening your patience
The reality many leaders miss? External chaos requires internal discipline.
Just published my daily leadership journal. Use code STOIC25 for 25% off.
#StoicLeadership #InnerCitadel #MentalFortitude #ResilientLeadership
[5 likes • 1 comment • 0 shares]

George Orwell sees Marcus Aurelius's post shared by a former colleague. Since getting laid off from the newspaper, he's been getting freelance work but AI is killing that now. He's attempting a Substack newsletter with precisely seven subscribers.
He tries with a post. Again. For the twentieth time this month.
Orwell posts:
⚠️ THE UNCOMFORTABLE TRUTH: The surveillance state isn't coming, it's already here!!
Inspired by @Marcus Aurelius's post on control and #ThoughtLeadership
Seeing MA's point about controlling what you can struck a nerve. The hard truth? You control far less than you think!
1️⃣ Language manipulation is the first step toward thought control
2️⃣ Technology enables unprecedented surveillance, welcomed in the name of convenience
3️⃣ Your social media isn't just being watched by you, it's watching you back!
Just launched my privacy newsletter Resistance on Substack! Link in comment section under this post. First 1,000 subscribers get my privacy audit toolkit free.
cc: @Friedrich Nietzsche your point about 'slave morality' has a modern equivalent: algorithmic compliance!
#DigitalEthics #InformationWarfare #CriticalThinking #PrivacyMatters
And who follows Orwell? Franz Kafka sees the post. Can't keep from leaving a comment:
@George your surveillance insights connect perfectly to workplace dehumanisation I've been studying. The corporate machine applies the same principles!
1️⃣ Your identity gradually merges with your function until indistinguishable!
2️⃣ The moment productivity falters, you're visible as a problem rather than a person!
3️⃣ Colleagues rationalise abandonment through bureaucratic language!
My workshop Preventing Employee Metamorphosis explores just that!
What part of your humanity have you sacrificed for professional advancement?
#CorporateSurvival #WorkplaceAlienation #CareerMetamorphosis #MondayMotivation #WorkLifeBalance #GreatResignation #QuietQuitting #BurnoutPrevention #MindfulLeadership
Mary Shelley follows Kafka, obviously. When she sees his comment on workplace dehumanisation immediately sends Hannah Arendt a quick vocal message:

Wow! Just saw Kafka's comment on workplace dehumanisation under Orwell's post. Perfect connection to my tech ethics framework! I'm going to post about creator responsibility and the Frankenstein effect in a bit. It'll work better in about an hour. But I need visibility! Help me! Can you share when it goes up? Love you! xx
And then, later, Mary posts:
⚠️ INNOVATION CAUTION!
@Franz Kafka's comment on @George Orwell's post inspired me to share the dark side of 'move fast and break things' - speaking of #TechEthics
Building on Franz's insights about dehumanisation and George's surveillance concerns. Here's what I've learned:
1️⃣ Pursuing innovation in isolation without diverse perspectives creates monsters
2️⃣ Rushing to launch without considering consequences leads to abandonment
3️⃣ Being first to market doesn't make you a hero, it makes you accountable for consequences
My ethics framework for preventing Frankenstein products is available as a free template.
Has your company ever released something without fully considering its impact?
#ResponsibleInnovation #TechEthics #DigitalHumanity
Marie Curie follows Shelley. Obviously, so much at stake in her field. Sends her friend Florence Nightingale a direct message:

Hey babe! Saw Shelley's post on tech ethics. Struggling to get funding for my research again. Maybe joining this thread could help? Your data visualisation skills + my radiation research observations = perfect combo! You in? Posting now. Comment? Thx! xx
And then Marie posts:
⚛️ BREAKTHROUGH METHODOLOGY: Seeing @Mary Shelley's ethics post reminded me why the most valuable discoveries come from persistent investigation!
Mary's framework on responsible innovation resonates deeply with my laboratory experience. Here's what we should always bear in mind!
1️⃣ The most significant discoveries often look like contamination or failures to the untrained eye!
2️⃣ Research isolation creates both breakthrough potential and ethical blind spots, careful!
3️⃣ True discovery requires risking everything. Including personal safety!
My radiation research methodology demonstrates how painstaking measurement reveals what conventional observation misses.
Seeking research partners and funding for continuation of work on new radioactive elements. DM for proposal. We're so close! Please share this post!
#RadiationResearch #ScientificMethodology #WomenInSTEM
A colleague suggested her content would perform better 'if she smiled more in her profile pic'
Florence Nightingale comments:

@Marie, your research methodology connects perfectly to my healthcare data work. Like your approach to radiation, I've found systematic data visualisation reveals invisible patterns! Visual data presentation creates urgency text reports cannot achieve, most deaths come from systematic failures, not individual cases, and the right visualisation overcomes entrenched resistance to change!!!
My healthcare dashboard template is free for non-profits and aims to reduce preventable deaths in hospitals.
Oh, and btw @George Orwell… data collection saves lives when applied ethically ;)
Visibility fading.
Engagement dropping.
The existential dread of irrelevance closing in.
What next?
Collaboration.
Talk about AI?
Cross promotion.
The Desperate Scramble Of Networking Over Substance

Henry Ford sits in his garage, staring at the prototype electric scooter he's been trying to fund for 18 months. Rejection emails from venture capital firms fill his inbox. Even worse, no emails. He's not into AI. He notices Florence's comment while searching LinkedIn for more investment leads.
He has to post. He needs to build a digital reputation, and not because he built something, but because he wants to build something. Whatever that means.
He posts about his plan. Takes a different angle this time:
Henry Ford posts:
🚗 DISRUPTION STRATEGY!!!!!!!
@Florence Nightingale's data-driven approach inspires me to share how deliberate system redesign transformed transportation!
Florence's visualisation work shows how system-level thinking drives change!
1️⃣ The assembly line isn't just a process improvement, it's a complete paradigm shift
2️⃣ Pay workers enough to buy your product (my proposed £20 hourly wage would shock competitors)
3️⃣ The masses represent a vastly larger market than the elite. Design for volume, not margin!
Currently seeking Series seed funding for my electric mobility venture. Hiring when funded!
@Simone de Beauvoir your point about action creating identity connects perfectly to how revolutionary production methods redefine entire industries.
#MassProduction #DisruptiveInnovation #VerticalIntegration #ScaleEconomics
Mahatma Gandhi sees Kafka's comment on Orwell's post and sends him a quick WhatsApp:

Hey dude! saw your comment on Orwell's post. I was thinking that your insights plus my non-violent communication work seem perfectly aligned. What if we collaborated on a joint workshop? Resisting Dehumanisation! From Workplace to Society! Feels like we attract more attention than our individual efforts. I have 0 clients right now & suspect you might be in similar situation. Together we might actually get some traction? Hit me back! Love ya! xx
Received. Seen. Silence.
Immediately messages Leonardo da Vinci with the same proposal

Leonardo da Vinci sits in a coffee shop with free wifi, nursing his third refill. His podcast 'The Polymath Advantage' has seventeen listeners after eight episodes. His student loan payments for his multiple degrees are three months overdue. It's a mess.
He needs more followers!
He needs to post more often. He's even changed his profile picture with AI now. Not because he liked it, because everyone did it.
So, Leonardo posts:

🔄 INTERDISCIPLINARY ADVANTAGE GO GO GO @Henry Ford's assembly line innovation and @Florence Nightingale's data vis showcase why the future belongs to those bridging disciplines. This is Renaissance Thinking!
Their approaches demonstrate perfectly what I've discovered across my career. Here my main takeaways!
1️⃣ Nature doesn't recognise our artificial disciplinary boundaries, so why should innovation?
2️⃣ The most valuable insights come from connecting seemingly unrelated domains!
3️⃣ Curiosity-driven learning outperforms purpose-driven expertise every day!
My Renaissance Thinking workshop aims to help teams break down silos. This is growth hacking done from the inside!
Is your organisation hiring for depth or breadth??? DM to unlock sustainable growth!
#InterdisciplinaryInnovation #PolymathAdvantage #RenaissanceThinking
He then likes his own post to nudge the algorithm. Not sure it actually helps.

Napoleon scrolls through LinkedIn during his lunch break at the telemarketing job he took to pay rent while his Bonaparte Victory Academy leadership consultancy struggles to attract clients. His bank account is down to €214.32, and his self-published book From Vision to Boardroom: Victory Strategies sits in boxes in his tiny apartment.

Suddenly, Nietzsche's post catches his eye. The ruthless rejection of traditional values, the embrace of power, the contempt for mediocrity. It's like reading his own game theory manifestos translated into philosophical language!
He sends a screenshot of Nietzsche's LinkedIn post to the 'Titans Networking' group chat:

OMG!!! Finally someone gets it! This Nietzsche dude is basically translating my entire strategy into philosophical terms! 'Slave morality' = exactly what I was posting against! 'Will to power' = my entire life's work! 🔥

We should all be following this approach instead of trying to sound politically correct in our 'thought leadership' content crap! Merde! @Julius remember how we talked about being more 'values-aligned' in our brand growth narrative? THIS is the opposite approach and I'm here for it!

I'm thinking of dming him about a collab - 'Beyond Good & Evil: Growth Strategies for Modern Leadership' workshop. My academy needs the boost. All in on this one?? Do it together? He's got digital presence that could help!
Been shadow-banned since my last post about 'conquering markets' so need a stronger ally
Franz Kafka sends Marcus Aurelius a WhatsApp:
Hey bro! Do you actually make any money doing this consulting thing or is everyone in this thought leadership space just pretending while driving Uber? Asking for a friend lol (the friend is me obvs)
And so it goes.
Day after day.
Genius reduced to growth hacking.
Philosophy packaged for consumption.
Revolutionary thought commodified into threads.
But what remains unseen?
What We've Lost
The Dark Ocean of NomPact
Would history's greatest minds today be desperate for visibility and algorithm favour?
Would they be networking relentlessly with tenuous connections?
Would they be constantly seeking to monetise profound ideas?
Would they be misinterpreting and simplifying complex concepts for marketability?
The thinkers who transformed civilisation, when reduced to pathetic growth hackers, would crush their revolutionary ideas into useless workshops and frameworks.
None of their value would survive them.
Note To Self
The algorithms that govern our attention would go as far as making genius invisible unless packaged into digestible, engagement optimised formats.
Bullet points.
What wisdom are we missing because it cannot survive the mechanics of metrics? Of engagement? Of monetisation?
What voices never reach us because they refuse to perform the dance required by our platforms?
Perhaps the most profound ideas are drowning in the dark ocean of forgotten content, while the most algorithm friendly content floats effortlessly to the surface.
Final Scene: Late that night
Socrates posts a simple question:

What is truth, if not the collective agreement on reality? And if so, how do we decide what is real when our reality is increasingly curated by invisible systems optimised not for truth but for engagement?'
Meanwhile, a paid partnership post from ThoughtInfluencer™:
'🔥🔥🔥🔥🔥 5 MORNING HABITS OF SUCCESSFUL PEOPLE!!! The QUICK Method to the 7 Figure Routine!!!' 👇👇👇💵💵💵👇👇👇
And Confucius?
Ah, Yes. He forgot to reply to Lao Tzu.
Message too far down and lost now.
Share Prismatica Lab

content.text: London's West End
I'm fighting against the human current flowing between Leicester Square and Piccadilly Circus. Swimming upstream through a river of bodies and intentions.

Bodies drift past me in chaotic choreography. Voices rise and fall like tidal waves crashing against my ears. Perfumes assault my senses. Some bearable. Others like direct punches to the face. Smartphones glow like handheld stars. Shopping bags and AppleWatches orbit wrists. Faces appear suspended, illuminated by the commercial constellations overhead.

The usual stuff. Nothing new. I spot an empty alley and move toward it, craving a detour from this trap of induced need. But just before escaping the chaos, I hesitate. I turn around to face the ocean of signals one more time. Something compels me to pause, to fight against the flood of stimuli, to search for anything. Anything at all. Anything worth genuinely noticing in this carefully engineered sensory assault.
The Neuroscience of Distraction

If Oliver Sacks were standing beside me right now, he'd point to how my brain is performing complex triage on this sensory flood. He'd explain the neuroscience with that gentle clarity of his. Bottom-up and top-down attention mechanisms wage silent war behind my eyes.

Those massive digital billboards in Piccadilly Circus aren't accidentally eye-catching. They're engineered to capture thirty-five percent more fixation time than human faces or natural elements. That's not coincidence but deliberate neurological exploitation. My visual cortex performs instant triage. Filtering information before I'm even aware it exists.

What serves as commercial leverage here once meant survival in the wild. Our executive control systems evolved to manage competing demands of foraging and threat detection. It's what Gladwell popularised as ‘thin-slicing’ in Blink. An adaptive neuro-visual strategy that once made us exceptional hunter-gatherers, now repurposed to make us exceptional consumers.
Our attention is perpetually vulnerable to capture. That's the evolutionary trade-off nobody mentions in those fucking marketing meetings.
Inversion

I notice a worker sweeping the pavement amid this sensory carnival. While everyone else flows past, his eyes track the crowd with an oddly archaeological attentiveness. Not watching so much as studying. As if we're artefacts from a civilisation he observes but doesn't inhabit. I find myself transfixed by this counter-current of attention, standing there watching him for a beat too long, when suddenly he turns and our eyes meet.

In that fleeting connection, something inverts. The observer becomes the observed. The subject becomes the object. The membrane between separate realities tears momentarily. I'm disoriented by the sudden shift in perspective. I'm no longer safely anonymous in the crowd. I've been seen.

My reaction is automatic, almost defensive. I smile briefly. Nod awkwardly as if saying 'thank you for cleaning our pavement.' I immediately look away. The alley I'd planned to escape into is forgotten as I rejoin the crowd, letting myself be swept back toward the Piccadilly Circus lights.

But something fundamental has shifted. The crowd no longer appears as separate individuals but as a single organism pulsing in response to invisible stimuli. Bodies move with eerie coordination. Guided by unseen planning and environmental cues. I've become a cell in this social body. My movements determined by forces I barely comprehend.
Through a Different Lens

That brief exchange of glances with the street sweeper suggested he perceives something in this hyper-designed urban landscape that remains completely invisible to me and thousands of others flowing past. He sees through what I merely see.

It reminds me of reading Emmanuel Carrère's The Moustache. That nightmarish story where a man shaves his facial hair only to discover no one notices the change. His reality fragments under collective misperception. My experience feels like the inverse of that crisis. Not a personal reality that others fail to validate, but a collective perception I've suddenly stepped outside of.

My brain has already decided, without my awareness or consent, what deserves my attention and what doesn't. I'm not perceiving reality. I'm filtering it through neural pathways carved by culture, class, and the deliberate design of urban environments. The street sweeper exists outside those filters, giving him a vantage point I can barely comprehend.

We're not seeing the world. We're seeing a carefully edited version that serves purposes both evolutionary and commercial. Perception operates as both inheritance and architecture. It's partly beast and partly Las Vegas. It's unavoidable.
High Street or The Strip?

The West End's commercial spaces share striking design elements with gambling establishments, something I've begun to notice since reading Natasha Dow Schüll's work on casino design in Addiction By Design The lighting isn't randomly bright but calibrated to a specific spectrum. The background music plays at precisely calculated beats-per-minute. Even the walking paths are mathematically optimised.

Retail consultant Paco Underhill documented this stuff with unnerving precision. Shoppers' walking pace slows by eighteen percent when entering these designed zones. Peripheral vision narrows by approximately twenty degrees under specific lighting conditions. Simple tactile interaction with merchandise increases purchase likelihood by sixty percent. Not casual observation. Behavioural engineering down to the decimal point.

The gambling parallel runs deeper than metaphor. Both environments employ controlled sight-lines preventing easy exits. Consistent flooring materials that eliminate subconscious boundaries. The conspicuous absence of clocks or windows that might orient you to time passing.

When I first encountered Schüll's descriptions of retired women wearing double layers of thick trousers at slot machines to avoid bathroom breaks, I was horrified. But now I see the same mechanisms of manipulation embedded in shopping districts, food courts, and social media interfaces. The architecture of captivation becomes terrifyingly literal.

These digital spaces represent the apotheosis of attention capture. Environments operating with algorithmic precision impossible in physical spaces. The algorithms learn your specific vulnerabilities in real-time, adjusting stimuli to your psychological profile with millisecond precision. That's not just commercial strategy. That's industrial-scale exploitation of human neuropsychology. That's your brain on capitalism, and it's fucked.
What We're Trained Not to See

Our selective perception reveals something unsettling: The barriers to seeing completely are simultaneously internal and external, physiological and social. Our thalamus filters a staggering ninety-nine percent of sensory data before it reaches what we call conscious awareness. Evolution decided long ago that complete perception would overwhelm us into paralysis.
But these filters don't just exclude irrelevant information. They exclude entire categories of people.

I've begun noticing how my own attention slides past certain individuals on these same streets. Not because they're literally invisible, but because my perceptual systems have been trained to categorise them as irrelevant background in that moment. The unhoused person sitting against a wall registers differently in my visual processing than the suited businessman walking past. This isn't a moral failing so much as a default neurological setting, but one with profound consequences.

What's chilling is how ordinary this blindness feels. It isn't a conscious dismissal. No internal monologue declares Ignore that person. Instead, it's a quiet arbitration by neural machinery refined over years of cultural conditioning. The Reticular Activation System (RAS), that ancient sieve in the brainstem, works in tandem with cortical systems that assign value to what we see. It learns, through repetition, what 'belongs' in a space: the businessman's sharp suit signals agent, actor, priority; the unhoused body, marked by tattered layers and stillness, slips into the category of non-agent, static, void.

This isn't passive oversight. It's active erasure. A collusion between biology and the stories we've internalised about who deserves attention, and care. The RAS filters, but society trains the filter. Daily activities, hourly news reports, wiring collective nervous systems to conflate human with relevant human.

The Journal of Experimental Social Psychology published a damning study on this. Shoppers in commercial districts were significantly less likely to notice individuals coded as 'homeless' compared to other pedestrians occupying the exact same visual field. These overlooked humans weren't invisible. They were systematically filtered out by nervous systems primed to prioritise specific social categories while dismissing others as irrelevant background.
The people we literally cannot see are, inevitably, the people whose needs we cannot address. It's not just sad. It's by design.
Parallel Realities in Shared Space

These perceptual filters aren't universal. Walking through Leicester Square, I experience one reality while the street sweeper experiences another, though we occupy identical physical coordinates. Not because he possesses some mystical insight, but because his practical relationship to this environment differs fundamentally from mine.

When urban anthropologist Robert Desjarlais interviews people experiencing homelessness, he consistently documents heightened awareness of urban elements completely invisible to housed residents: Those divided benches with armrests placed specifically to prevent lying down. Surveillance patterns mapping safe and unsafe zones. Unofficial territorial boundaries. These aren't separate physical environments but separate perceptual ones occupying the same space.

In my own experience as someone with sensory processing differences, I notice the fluorescent lights that others don't consciously register. I detect patterns in background noise that most filter out as random sound. I feel textures with such intensity that touching certain materials borders on intolerable.

These aren't special powers but alternative perceptual frameworks. Each with advantages and costs in navigating a world designed for different neural wiring. The same space that represents leisure and consumption to one person might represent exclusion and surveillance to another. Same physical space. Different lived reality.
Breaking Through Perceptual Barriers

The capacity to shift these perceptual filters isn't merely theoretical. Attention is remarkably trainable. When I go for hikes I do my best to practice mindfulness. I’m constantly startled by how quickly my baseline perception shifts. Sounds I'd usually filtered out become noticeable. Visual details emerge from what would otherwise seemed uniform backgrounds. The neural architecture literally rewires in response to how we direct our attention.
It's difficult work. Exhausting, really. Going against your brain's natural filtering feels like swimming upstream. But it's possible.

What fascinates me most is how theoretical frameworks shape what we're capable of perceiving. The history of science demonstrates this repeatedly: what appears as meaningless noise to researchers in one paradigm becomes recognised as crucial data in another. Reality doesn't change, but what we're capable of extracting from it transforms dramatically.

This raises provocative questions: what is the broader social effect of our current perceptual barriers? If perception fundamentally dictates awareness, what are the limits of human experience? Could our perceived reality be potentially infinite if we developed the right attentional practices?
Or more practically: what the hell else am I missing right now?
The Ethics of Seeing

The relationship between perception and ethics isn't abstract theory. It's been the essential question of virtually every philosophical tradition across cultures. These thinkers recognised a fundamental truth: how we perceive directly shapes what we value, and consequently, how we act in the world. Your perceptual framework becomes your ethical framework by default.

Brain imaging studies confirm this ancient insight. When subjects categorise others as outside their social group, regions associated with empathy show measurably reduced activation. The neural circuits that enable us to feel others' pain literally dim when perceiving someone as 'other.' This isn't moral failure. It's the default setting of our perceptual hardware.

I see this manifesting constantly in what might be called 'selective grief.' It operates every time we react with intense emotional response to suffering only when the victims resemble those we identify with. The Syrian child and the European child may face identical circumstances, yet our emotional systems process these identical realities through entirely different circuits based on perceived similarity and difference.

The uncomfortable truth is that perceptual filters have profound ethical implications not because some ways of seeing are inherently more moral than others, but because perception determines which factors even enter our ethical calculations in the first place. What we cannot or do not perceive never makes it to the table of moral consideration.

But this perceptual constraint isn't immutable fate. It's a wall that can be demolished, though not without significant effort. Sometimes it takes a street sweeper looking you in the eye to realise how much you've been missing.
Note To Self
Remember this moment.
Remember how it felt when the street sweeper looked at you and suddenly you weren't invisible anymore.

Stop letting your brain filter out what doesn't immediately serve you. Notice the benches designed so homeless people can't sleep on them. Notice the security guards who blend into the background until someone 'unwanted' appears.
Notice how your own attention is being guided without your permission.
You don't want to be just another body flowing through commercially optimised space, eyes fixed on the next purchase point. That's what they've designed you to be. That's the trap.
Keep practicing this double vision.
See both the world as it's presented and the mechanisms behind the curtain. It's exhausting, but necessary.
Your attention is valuable. That's why everyone's trying to steal it.
When you feel yourself being pulled along predetermined paths, pause. Look around.
Ask yourself:
What am I being directed not to see?
Who benefits from my current perception?
You're not going to dismantle hostile capitalism by noticing hostile architecture. But noticing is the first step to not being completely controlled by it.
Start small. Notice more. Filter less. Trust that uneasy feeling when something seems designed to manipulate you. It usually is.
The better world isn't going to suddenly appear because you've expanded your perception.
But you can't create what you can't first imagine.
And you can't imagine what you've been trained not to see.
Or put more bluntly. Wake the fuck up.
